tn.text: This refers to the message that Yahweh spoke. AT: "the message of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: completely destroy all that they have ... kill both man and woman, child and infant, ox and sheep, camel and donkey
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing. The second phrase gives specific details about what they are to destroy completely. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This negative statement emphasizes the completeness of the destruction. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
"the army"
"counted them"
a city in southern Judah (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: two hundred thousand men on foot, and ten thousand men of Judah
tn.text: "200,000 men on foot, and 10,000 men of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
a nomad people group that had always been friendly to the nation of Israel (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Yahweh had told Saul to destroy everything, but here Saul disobeys Yahweh's command.
"he captured Agag"
The phrase, "the edge of the sword," here is a synecdoche that represents the army of the nation of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Saul disobeyed God by letting Agag live.

tn.ref: as well as the best of the sheep
tn.text: Saul disobeyed God by keeping the best of the livestock.
This is an idiom that means Yahweh spoke. AT: "Yahweh spoke his word" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "word" represents Yahweh's message. AT: "the message of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"I am sorry" (UBD)

tn.ref: he has turned back from following me
tn.text: Saul not obeying Yahweh is spoken of as if Saul had physically turned away from walking behind God. AT: "he has stopped following me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"has not obeyed what I commanded him to do." Saul was to completely destroy everything and everyone. God had placed a ban on the Amalekites. But Saul permitted some livestock to live.
Possible meanings are 1) Samuel was angry with Saul for his disobedience or 2) Samuel was disturbed (UDB).
"Someone told Samuel"

tn.ref: he set up a monument to himself
tn.text: Saul was full of pride.
Gilgal was lower in elevation than Carmel.

tn.ref: I have fulfilled the command of Yahweh
tn.text: It is not clear if Saul understood that he had not fully obeyed God's command to completely destroy the Amalekites.
Samuel questions why Saul did not utterly destroyed the Amalekites.

tn.ref: bleating of sheep ... lowing of the oxen
tn.text: These are the sounds that these animals make. Your language may have different terms for these.

tn.ref: in my ears ... that I hear
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing. Here "in my ears" refers to hearing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: They have brought ... the people spared
tn.text: The word "they" and the phrase "the people" here both represent Saul's army. Saul is blaming the people rather than himself.

tn.ref: to sacrifice to Yahweh your God
tn.text: Saul is arguing that animals for sacrifice were an exception to Yahweh's command to destroy everything.
Saul here does not describe Samuel's God as his own God.
Here "sight" refers to his opinion based on what he saw. AT: "in your own opinion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: were you not made the head of the tribes of Israel?
tn.text: Samuel uses this question to remind Saul of now much God had given him. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Yahweh made you the ruler of the tribes of Israel!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Why did you not obey ... Yahweh?
tn.text: Samuel asks this question to rebuke Saul for disobeying Yahweh. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "You should have obeyed ... Yahweh!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "voice" refers to the commands that Yahweh spoke. AT: "the things that Yahweh commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: but instead you seized the booty
tn.text: Samuel is accusing Saul of direct disobedience. Yahweh commanded Saul to completely destroy everything belonging to the Amalekites, and not to bring anything back to camp.
"the plunder" or "the possessions you took from the enemy"

tn.ref: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: Here "sight" refers to Yahweh's thoughts or opinion. AT: "what Yahweh considers to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I have indeed obeyed the voice of Yahweh
tn.text: This is an emphatic statement. It is unclear if Saul thought this was true, or if he was simply making excuses for his sin.
Here "voice" refers to the commands that Yahweh spoke. AT: "the things that Yahweh commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the name of the king of the Amalekites. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This appears to be shifting the blame to the people.
"animals that Yahweh commanded them to destroy"
This is the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Has Yahweh as much delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices, as in obeying the voice of Yahweh?
tn.text: Samuel asks this question to emphasize that obedience is much more important than sacrifice. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "Yahweh does not delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices as much as in obeying his voice!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "voice" refers to the commands that Yahweh spoke. AT: "the things that Yahweh commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
God wanted Saul's complete obedience in the destruction of the Amalekites. Nothing in the land was fit for sacrifice.

tn.ref: better than the fat of rams
tn.text: "better than to sacrifice the fat of rams as a burnt offering"

tn.ref: rebellion is like the sin of divination
tn.text: These abstract nouns can be stated as actions. AT: "to rebel is as sinful as doing sorcery" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: stubbornness is like wickedness and iniquity
tn.text: These abstract nouns can be stated as actions. AT: "being stubborn is as sinful as worshiping idols" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here "word" refers to the command that Yahweh spoke. AT: "refused to do what Yahweh commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"decided that you will no longer be king"
This is an idiom that means he had disobeyed the commandment. AT: "I have disobeyed what Yahweh commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: because I was afraid of the people
tn.text: This is the reason Saul gives for not obeying God. AT: "because I was afraid of the soldiers"
Here "voice" refers to what the soldiers asked Saul to do. AT: "did what they asked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Saul and Samuel were apparently talking in private away from the other people.

tn.ref: for you have rejected the word of Yahweh
tn.text: Samuel made it clear that Saul understood that he was disobeying God at the time when he spared the best animals and did not kill Agag.
Here "word" refers to the command that Yahweh spoke. AT: "refused to do what Yahweh commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Saul took hold of the hem of his robe
tn.text: Saul did this to try to stop Samuel from leaving. This can be stated explicitly. AT: "Saul tried to stop him by grabbing the edge of Samuel's robe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the edge of his robe" or "the fringe of his robe"

tn.ref: Yahweh has torn the kingdom of Israel
tn.text: This refers back to when Saul tore Samuel's robe in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:15:26|15:27]]. This can be made explicit. AT: "Just as you tore my robe, Yahweh has torn the kingdom of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: has given it to a neighbor of yours, one who is better than you
tn.text: God had already decided who would be the next king after Saul.
This idiom refers to Yahweh, who gives strength to the Israelites. AT: "Yahweh, who is the strength of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: will not lie nor change his mind
tn.text: This is stated as a negative to emphasize that God tells the truth. This can be stated in positive form. AT: "will always tell the truth and do what he says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
This refers to his thoughts and decisions. AT: "what he has decided to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: he is not a man, that he should change his mind
tn.text: This is stated as a negative to emphasize that God is trustworthy. This can be stated in positive form. AT: "he is God, and will do what he says he will do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: But please honor me now before the elders
tn.text: Saul may have been more interested in being honored by the people than in actually worshipping God.

tn.ref: before the elders of my people and before Israel
tn.text: Here "Israel" refers to the people of Israel. AT: "before the people of Israel and the elders who lead them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Come back with me" or "Return with me"

tn.ref: So Samuel turned again after Saul
tn.text: This implies that Samuel changed his mind, and that they went together to where the people were. AT: "So Samuel finally agreed to do that, and they went together back to where the people were" (UDB)

tn.ref: Agag came to him confined with chains and said
tn.text: "They brought Agag to him bound by chains and Agag said"

tn.ref: Surely the bitterness of death has past
tn.text: This idiom appears to mean that Agag no longer thought he would be killed. AT: "Surely I am no longer in danger or dying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: As your sword has made women childless, so shall your mother be childless among women
tn.text: Both of these phrases have similar meaning and may be intended to be in poetic form. AT: "Since you have killed people, you will also be killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: made women childless, so shall your mother be childless
tn.text: This is a polite way of referring to killing people. AT: "killed the sons of other women, so shall I kill your mother's son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: Then Samuel chopped Agag to pieces
tn.text: Samuel is the one who completed this task that Yahweh commanded Saul to do. AT: "Then Samuel cut Agag into pieces with his sword" (UDB)
These are the names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names ]])

tn.ref: went up to his house at Gibeah
tn.text: Gibeah was higher in elevation than Gilgal where Saul and Samuel had been talking.

tn.ref: Samuel did not see Saul until the day of his death
tn.text: This statement is very precise and should be translated carefully. Samuel died before Saul and did not see Saul again while he lived. However, Samuel did appear to Saul in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:28:11|28:11-19]] after Samuel died.
